metadata.title: A new diclofenac molecularly imprinted electrochemical sensor based upon a polyaniline/reduced graphene oxide nano-composite

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Biosensors and Bioelectronics
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/bios
A new diclofenac molecularly imprinted electrochemical sensor based upon a polyaniline/reduced graphene oxide nano-composite
Maryam Mostafavi, Mohammad Reza Yaftian⁎, Farideh Piri, Hassan Shayani-Jam Phase Equilibria Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, The University of Zanjan, Postal Code 45371-38791 Zanjan, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Diclofenac Molecularly imprinted polymer Polyaniline Reduced graphene oxide Electrochemical sensor
A B S T R A C T
A diclofenac (DCF)-imprinted polymer, composed of polyaniline, reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and triphenylamine, as cross linker, was synthetized. This composite was identified by using SEM and FT-IR techniques. The prepared DCF-imprinted polymer (MIP) was used for modification of carbon paste electrodes (CPEs) to fabricate a selective DCF electrochemical sensor. Electrochemical behavior of DCF on the investigated sensor and the optimization of the parameters affecting the DCF determination were screened by cyclic voltammetry (CV). The cyclic voltammogram of DCF showed an anodic peak current at about 0.5 V (vs. SCE). The calibration curve for DCF determination was obtained by applying the investigated sensor as working electrode in differential pulse voltammetry (DPV). A linear increase in the anodic peak current was observed in the range 5–80mg L−1 of DCF. The corresponding limit of detection was calculated to be 1.1 mg L−1. The relative standard deviations of the inter- and intra-day analysis of DCF presented by the method were found to be as 2.43% and 2.47%, respectively. The selectivity of the investigated sensor was evaluated by its use for determination of DCF in the binary solutions containing DCF/glucose, DCF/urea and DCF/ascorbic acid. It was shown that the fabricated electrode can be successfully used for analysis of DCF in pharmaceutical and urine samples.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Diclofenac is a member of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) which are used in remedy of several diseases (Silverstein et al., 2000). This medicine is widely used in a variety of medical treatment including eye surgery, rheumatoid arthritis therapy, sports injuries and osteoarthritis (Hassan et al., 2005; Yang et al., 2008; Duncan and Farr, 1988). Its carboxymethyl ester derivative is metabolized to DCF and it has also anti-inflammatory activity (Hinz et al., 2003). The action of DCF is resulted from its role as an inhibitor of cyclooxygenase enzyme which prohibits the production of prostaglandins (Kormosh et al., 2007). While the medical aspects of DCF are outstanding, it has some side effects such as aplastic anemia, hemolytic anemia, hematological toxicity, hepatitis, neutropenia and thrombocytopenia (Miyamoto et al., 1997).
The relatively wide clinical use of DCF stimulates researchers to develop the methods and techniques for its determination in various biological and pharmaceutical samples (Santini et al., 2006). The techniques already used for determination of DCF included HPLC (Kasperek, 2008), HPLC-MS (Abdel-Hamid et al., 2001), TLC (Sun and Fabre, 1994), GC (Sioufi et al., 1991), derivative spectrophotometry (Ulu, 2011), capillary zone electrophoresis and chemometric methods
(Jin and Zhang, 2000). Nevertheless, a necessity to develop the methods bearing simple operation, inexpensive, selective, and reliable characteristics, with ability for DCF determination in different samples is yet felt.
Beside the aforementioned methods, electrochemical techniques are applied for analysis of DCF. These techniques are known as the methods with good sensitivity, appropriate selectivity, inexpensive, time-saving and simple operation. These advantages encouraged research groups to design voltammetric based procedures for assessment of DCF in pharmaceutical and biological samples (Vlascici et al., 2010; Goyal et al., 2010). Carbon paste electrodes (CPEs) are widely used as working electrode in voltammetric methods because they are applicable in a wide potential range with renewable surface, low cost, simple, and they can be rapidly prepared (Svancara et al., 2001). Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that the modification of CPEs results in significant improvement of their electro-analytical performances (Karim-Nezhad et al., 2017).
Molecular Imprinting Technology (MIT) is a technique to design artificial receptors called Molecularly Imprinted Polymers (MIPs). In the two past decades, the preparation of MIPs and their applications have attracted the interest of many research groups with different interests (Lingxin et al., 2011). A MIP is constructed by a polymer with
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bios.2018.09.047 Received 27 June 2018; Received in revised form 9 September 2018; Accepted 12 September 2018
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: yaftian@znu.ac.ir (M.R. Yaftian).
Biosensors and Bioelectronics 122 (2018) 160–167
Available online 13 September 2018 0956-5663/ © 2018 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
cavities in its matrix. These cavities are potential to interact selectively with the analyte (template molecule) (Blanco-Lopez et al., 2004). MIPs have been applied in chemical separations (Wang et al., 2006), preparation of catalysts (Mirata and Resmini, 2015) and development of molecular sensors (Mujahid and Dickert, 2012). The important aspect of the MIPs-based sensors is their highly selective characteristics due to their potential for binding selectively the target compounds. It has been shown that the application of MIPs for modification of working electrodes of voltammetric technique leads to selective methods for determination of various substances (Zakaria et al., 2009; Lian et al., 2015) including DCF (Blanco‐Lopez et al., 2007).
The present paper intends to report the construction of modified carbon paste electrodes by a molecularly imprinted nano-composite polymer for determination of DCF. The investigated MIP was synthesized by using polyaniline, a cross-linker (triphenylamine) and reduced graphene oxide. The conductive nature of polyaniline makes it suitable for using as the base polymer for fabricating the target MIP. Application of triphenylamine allowed the three dimension polymers, and the presence of rGO increased the efficiency of DCF-MIP etching. In addition, it is reported that the presence of rGO together with other nanomaterials and other inorganic or organic conductive products offers an electro-catalytic activities and make the fast electron transfer process possible (Zaidi and Shin, 2014). The prepared materials were characterized by SEM and FT-IR techniques. The electrochemical investigations were followed by cyclic voltammetry and differential pulse voltammetry methods.

sections.heading: 2.1. Reagents and materials
sections.text: Potassium salt of diclofenac (99.6%, Amoli Organics, India), aniline (for analysis, Merck, Germany), triphenylamine (for synthesis, Aldrich, USA), ammonium persulfate (ACS reagent, Fluka, Switzerland), paraffin (Ph Eur, Merck, Germany), graphite powder (extra pure, Merck, Germany), sodium hydroxide (extra pure, Merck, Germany), perchloric acid (for analysis, Merck, Germany), hydrochloric acid (for analysis, Merck, Germany), ortho-phosphoric acid (pure, Fluka, Switzerland), acetic acid (GR, Dr. Mojallali, Iran), ammonia solution (extra pure, Merck, Germany), acetonitrile (Ph Eur, Merck, Germany) and ethanol (96%, Hamoun Teb, Iran) were used as received. Dimethyl sulfoxide (for spectroscopy, Merck, Germany), lithium perchlorate (ACS reagent, Sigma-Aldrich, USA) and graphite rods were applied in the procedure used for obtaining reduced graphene oxide. Potassium chloride (extra pure, Merck, Germany), sodium chloride (Ph Eur, Carlo Erba, Spain) and potassium hexacyanoferrate(III) (Ph Eur, Merck, Germany) were used for the experiments realized for evaluating the active surface area of the sensor. Urea (for biochemistry, Merck, Germany), glucose (Dextrose Company, Iran) and ascorbic acid (Synthetic Reag., Merck, Germany) were used in the experiments performed for evaluating the selectivity of the developed sensor. Degassing of solutions was performed with nitrogen gas (> 99.99%) stream.

sections.heading: 2.2. Apparatus
sections.text:
Cyclic and differential pulse voltammograms were recorded on a Metrohm voltammeter (model 797 VA computrace, Switzerland) by using a three-electrode system. Modified and unmodified carbon paste electrodes were used as working electrodes. Saturated calomel electrode (SCE) and a platinum wire were used as reference and counter electrodes, respectively. Fourier-transform infrared spectra were recorded on a FT-IR Brucker-Vector 22 spectrophotometer (Bruker, Germany). Scanning electron microscopy (MIRA3TESCAN, USA), X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance, Germany) and element analyzer (elementar Analysen systeme GmbH-vario EL III, Germany) were used to characterize the synthetized materials. High performance liquid
chromatography (Shimadzu, Japan) was used, as a reference method to determine DCF in pharmaceutical and urine samples, for the method validation investigations. A double beam spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, UV-240, Japan) was applied for recording the UV–Vis absorption spectra. A Metrohm pH meter (Metrohm 780, Switzerland) was used for pH measurements. An ultrasonic cleaner (power sonic 405, Korea) was used for ultrasonic irradiations. Zolalan, M-UV-3+ water purification system (Iran) provided deionized water with a resistivity of ≥18.2MΩ. Power supply (Shargh Azma, Iran) was used to apply DC voltage in the preparation step of rGO.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of reduced graphene oxide (rGO)
sections.text: Reduced graphene oxide was synthesized based on the slightly modified method of Zhou et al. (2013). The anode and cathode used in this procedure were graphite rods, and the intercalation reagents were prepared by a mixture of HCl/DMSO (1:5mol ratio) and lithium perchlorate (0.1 g L−1) dissolved in deionized water. Exfoliation of graphite cathode was started by applying a DC voltage (12 V). The electrolyte containing edge exfoliated graphite was first filtered. After washing with ethanol and deionized water, the obtained suspension was shelved overnight, for completion the settle down of the solid particles. Then it was treated by ultrasonic irradiation for 60min. The graphite flakes in the mixture was separated by centrifugation.

sections.heading: 2.4. Synthesis of DCF-imprinted polymer
sections.text: DCF-imprinted polymer was prepared by mixing 15mL of deionized water, 40mL ethanol and 0.21 g triphenylamine. This mixture was ultrasonically irradiated to dissolve the solid materials. After addition of 2mL aniline to this mixture, the ultrasonic irradiation was continued for 5min. Then, rGO (0.15 g), potassium diclofenac salt (0.3 g) and ammonium persulfate (1.0 g) were added to this mixture, and the blend was sonicated in an ice bath for 100min. The produced nano-composite was centrifuged and washed three times with ethanol and, subsequently three times with deionized water. The template was extracted by contacting the template containing, two times, the MIP with 100mL deionized water under intensive ultrasonic irradiation for 90min. The non-imprinted polymer (NIP) was prepared in a similar way which was used for the preparation of DCF-MIP described above, except that the potassium diclofenac salt was not added during the synthesis.

sections.heading: 2.5. Preparation of DCF sensor
sections.text: To prepare the carbon paste electrode modified with DCF-imprinted polymer (MIP–CPE) or with non-imprinted polymer (NIP–CPE), 0.02 g of graphite was homogenized in a mortar with 0.005 g of the prepared MIP or NIP. Subsequently, the prepared blend was added to paraffin (0.01 g) and mixed with a stainless steel spatula. Finally, the homogenized paste was inserted into a plastic needle-type capillary tube with 1.2 mm diameter and 5mm length, using a copper wire connected to the measurement system. The surface of the prepared electrodes was cleaned by polishing them on a paper sheet.

sections.heading: 2.6. Electrochemical investigations
sections.text: An appropriate volume of the stock solution of DCF (100mg L−1) was diluted to 50.0 mL with HClO4 solution (0.1 mol L−1) in a volumetric flask. This solution was transferred into the voltammetric cell and it was purged with nitrogen gas stream for 5min, before recording the voltammograms. The CVs corresponding to the fifth scan were recorded and used in the quantitative studies.

sections.heading: 2.7. Applications of the sensor
sections.text:
The applicability of the developed sensor was evaluated by using it
for determination of DCF in a commercial DCF injection solution (Caspian Company, Rasht, Iran), in tablets containing DCF (Sobhan Darou Company, Tehran, Iran) and in urine samples. In order to prepare the injection solution for the DCF analysis, 2 mL of commercial injection solution contained 25mgmL−1 of DCF (labeled by the company) was diluted to 1000mL of HClO4 (0.1 mol L−1). For determination of DCF in the tablet sample (labeled 50mg per tablet), five tablets were grinded and homogenized. A weight of 25mg of the obtained powder was dissolved in 100mL deionized water by assistance of ultrasonic irradiation. Then, the mixture was filtered and 10mL of which was subsequently transferred into a 100mL volumetric flask and diluted to the mark with HClO4 solution (0.1 mol L−1). The fresh urine samples were taken from three independent patients who consumed DCF. The samples were stored in refrigerator (-4 °C). The samples were centrifuged (2500 rpm) for 30min and then filtered by a filter paper. The urine samples were measured by standard addition method. In a 25mL volumetric flask was added of 5mL of urine samples and 0–5mL of standard solution (10mg L−1 of diclofenac in 0.1 mol L−1 HClO4). The flasks were then filled with 0.1 mol L−1 HClO4. The solutions were transferred to the voltammetric cell and the analysis were done by using DPV method. All the measurements were performed triplicate.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of the prepared layered reduced graphene oxide
sections.text:
Layered reduced graphene oxide (rGO) was prepared by electrochemical intercalation of graphite cathode using HCl/DMSO solution as intercalation reagent. Fig. S1 shows the SEM images of the prepared rGO. The most of rGO flakes have nano-size layered structure. This structure leads to their conductive characteristics. In fact, the layered structure allows the diffusion of electrolyte into the interspace of rGO sheets and thus enhances their conductive characteristics (Stankovich et al., 2007).
The presence of a sharp signal in the XRD pattern (Fig. S2) indicated that the produced rGO particles bear lower defects. A comparison of the XRD pattern of the rGO particle prepared electrochemically in this study with that synthesized by chemical methods (Stankovich et al., 2007), demonstrated that the former rGOs bear fewer oxygen containing functional groups.

sections.heading: 3.2. Characterization of the prepared polymer
sections.text:
In order to extract the template (DCF) from the synthesized nanocomposite (imprinting procedure), 100mL deionized water was added and the mixture was sonicated for 90min. This procedure was repeated two times. The UV–Vis spectrum of the solution resulted from the washed nano-composite was compared with the UV spectrum of 10−4 mol L−1 DCF (Fig. S3). This investigation showed the suitability of water, under applied condition, for exiting the template from the prepared imprinted polymer.
In order to make sure the complete depletion of the template (DCF) from the nano-composite structure, the imprinted polymer was used for recording the CV of blank and DCF (5mg L−1) solutions in the presence of supporting electrolyte HClO4 (0.1 mol L−1). A comparison of the voltammograms (Fig. S4) showed that, in contrast to the CV of the DCF contained solution, which showed an anodic and a cathodic signal at 0.52 and 0.31 V (vs. SCE), respectively, the corresponding CV for the blank solution demonstrated very weak peaks, which allowed concluding a suitable depletion of the template from the prepared nanocomposite.
The SEM images of the prepared NIP and MIP materials (Fig. S5), demonstrated a typical morphology of them. It can be seen that the irregular sheets of nano-composites are formed on the surface of the prepared rGO and porous clustered structures were growing on the surface of the separated plates of the MIP, while such cluster structure
was not observed on the NIP material. The EDS analysis (Fig. S6) showed that the prepared MIP contains 61.5% carbon, 27% nitrogen and 10.5% oxygen. Although the EDS analysis did not present information inside the imprinting process and creation of the cavities in the prepared MIP, it showed the elemental distribution of the imprinted polymer. The absence of sulfur atom confirmed that the subsidiary reactions which may be taken place during the polymerization in the presence of ammonium persulfate cannot be taken place.
The FT-IR spectra of DCF-imprinted polymer (MIP), non-imprinted polymer (NIP) and monomer (aniline) were recorded by preparing their KBr pellets (Fig. S7). The spectrum of aniline showed two bands around 3400 cm−1. These bands were attributed to the symmetrical and asymmetrical N–H stretching vibrations of the amine groups. The observed band at 1272 cm−1 was related to C–N stretching vibration of aromatic amines. The FT-IR spectra of MIP and NIP were very similar. The observed peak at about 840 cm−1 confirms the dominating paracoupling of constitutional aniline units in polymerization process. For both of the materials the C–N stretching bands appeared at 1294 cm−1. The presence of C˭N stretching bands for both of these materials were shown by the peaks appeared at about 1635 cm−1. The peaks observed at 3054 and 3051 cm−1, in the FT-IR spectra of MIP materials were correspondingly attributed to their aromatic C–H stretching vibrations. The N–H stretches of these polymers were seen at the wavenumbers 3292 cm−1 for both MIP and NIP.
Although the FT-IR spectrum of the MIP containing DCF could not help to find clear information for DCF and MIP binding sites interactions; π-π interactions, hydrogen bindings and the interactions of the loan pair electrons of nitrogen atoms and the carbon atoms with electron deficiency (i.e. C˭O and C˭N) can be suggested as the main interactions for this system. Based on this suggestion a schematic representation for the modality of the template binding with the MIP was proposed as that shown in Fig. S8.

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrochemical behavior of [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− couple on the investigated sensor
sections.text:
In order to elucidate the electrochemical behavior of the investigated MIP electrode, the cyclic voltammograms of the redox reaction of [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− couple obtained on a carbon paste electrode (CP) were compared with those recorded by using the MIP-modified carbon paste electrode (MIP-CP). Fig. 1 shows the cyclic voltammograms of a solution of K3[Fe(CN)6] (1.0 mmol L−1) and NaCl (0.1 mol L−1), recorded on the CP and MIP-CP electrodes. The voltammograms showed a peak-to-peak separation (ΔEp) of 0.417 V at CP electrode. This value was lower at MIP-CP electrode (0.248 V).
The observed decrease in ΔEp value at the MIP-CP electrode may be described by considering a more reversible charge-transfer process on the MIP-CP electrode with respect to that on the CP electrode (Sheela et al., 2011), which may be attributed to a possible catalytic effect of the added nano-composite to carbon paste.
The results shown on Fig. 1 revealed also that the magnitude of redox peak current for [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− couple was enhanced at modified carbon paste electrode MIP-CP. The observed increase in Ip values was described by considering the role of modifier in increasing the active surface area of the electrode (Kalambate et al., 2016). This argument was tested by estimating the active surface area of the CP and MIP electrodes via Randles−Sevcik equation (Kalambate et al., 2016):
= ×I 2.69 10 n AD C *νp 5 3/2 01/2 0 1/2 (1)
The parameters Ip, n, A, D0, n and C0* refer to the anodic peak current, the number of electrons transferred, the surface area of the electrode, the diffusion coefficient, the potential scan rate, and the concentration of the redox couple, respectively.
For evaluating the active surface of the investigated electrode cyclic
voltammograms of a solution of K3[Fe(CN)6] (1 mmol L−1) in the presence of NaCl (0.1 mol L−1) at different potential scan rates were obtained (figure not shown). For this system, “n” equals to 1 and the value of “D0” is reported as 7.6×10−6 cm2 s−1 (Chethana et al., 2012). By plotting the variation of “Ip” as a function of “υ1/2” (Fig. S9), the active surface area of the electrodes was calculated. The evaluated surface area of the CP and MIP-CP electrodes were found to be 0.013 ± 0.001 and 0.019 ± 0.002 cm2, respectively. This showed an enhancement in active surface area of about 46% of the modified electrode with respect to the unmodified CP electrode. These results confirmed the role of the MIP on the enhancement of active surface area on the Ip values and also its possible catalytic effect which could result in decreasing the values of ΔEp.

sections.heading: 3.4. Electrochemical behavior of DCF
sections.text:
The cyclic voltammograms (five runs) of DCF on a carbon paste electrode (Fig. S10) showed an irreversibly oxidation peak (A1) at 0.98 V and a redox couple peaks A2 and C2, at about 0.50 V. The current of peak A1 decreased from run 1–5, in contrast the current peak A2 was raised. The mechanism of the electrochemical behavior of DCF on the carbon paste electrode has been already given by Goyal et al. (2010). This mechanism consisted of two steps (Fig. S11). The initial step involves two electrons abstraction from DCF, concurrently with this process 2 protons abstraction from DCF and intermediate reacts with water and undergoes through aromatization product (II) is formed. This step is in accordance to the peak I in CVs shown in Fig. S10. The second step involves a quasi-reversible redox process created the product (III), which is related to the peaks A2 and C2.
Fig. 2 contains the cyclic voltammograms (fifth scan) of DCF solution in the presence of perchloric acid using CP and modified CP electrodes with MIP (MIP-CP) and NIP (NIP-CP). The observed peaks A2 and C2 on the MIP–CP electrode, correspond to the redox process of compounds (II) and (III) (Scheme 2), were noticeably higher than that found on NIP–CP and unmodified CP electrodes. This enhancement was attributed to the existence and proper structure of cavities of the MIP which permit a selective and efficient entrapment of the analyte in the
modified MIP-CP electrode. It is worth of note that the A1 peak decreased and A2 peak increased by raising the number of scans. It was seen that the height of these peaks remains unchanged after five scans. Thus, although the mechanism of the oxidation of DCF on both unmodified CP and modified MIP-CP was the same. The A1 peak cannot be observed in Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 3.5. Optimization of the parameters influencing MIP-CP
3.5.1. MIP–CP composition
sections.text: For optimization of the amount of MIP in the sensor, various compositions including 0.02 g graphite, 0.01 g paraffin and an amount of the prepared MIP in the range 0.0005–0.008 g of MIP were examined. The cyclic voltammograms of the solution of DCF at modified CP electrodes with different mass of the MIP were recorded (Fig. S12). This investigation was followed by determination of the anodic peak current of DCF on the examined sensors. It was seen that the “Ip” increased with the MIP mass in the range 0.0005–0.006 g. A current independency to the amount of MIP was observed beyond 0.006 g. Application of more than 0.008 g of the MIP caused unsuitable mechanical stability of the electrode. As the optimal modifier concentration must be selected in such a way that the highest current value with the largest signal to background current (Kia et al., 2011), the electrode contained 0.02 g graphite, 0.01 g paraffin and 0.006 g of MIP, which gave the highest peak intensity was selected for following the experiments.

sections.heading: 3.5.2. Effect of the solution pH
sections.text:
The solution pH dependency of the DCF oxidation at the MIP-CP electrode was investigated by recording the corresponding CVs in the pH range of 1.0–6.0 (Fig. 3a). It was seen that the peak current decreased with an increase in pH, and the anodic peak potential shifted to the less positive potentials. A maximum peak current was found by adjusting the solution to pH 1.0. This effect confirmed the participation of protons in the redox reactions of DCF, as it is demonstrated by the Nernst equation (Eq. (2)) for a general half-reaction (Si et al., 2014); Ox + ne‐ + mH+ ⇌ Red.
⎜ ⎟′ = ′ + ⎛ ⎝ ⎞ ⎠ − ⎛ ⎝
⎞ ⎠ E E RT nF ln [Ox] [Red] 2.303mRT nF pHp 0 (2)
The variation of E′p as a function of pH showed at Fig. 3b. The slope of the first linear region was found as 57.8 mV/pH. The closeness of this slope to the theoretical value (59mV/pH) indicated the equal number of proton and electron are participated in the electrochemical process (Fotouhi et al., 2012). Thus, the obtained slope showed participation of the same electrons and protons in electro-redox process of DCF.

sections.heading: 3.6. Potential scan rate and the electrode reaction mechanism
sections.text: Fig. 4a shows the cyclic voltammograms of DCF at the MIP-CP electrode obtained with various potential scan rates (υ) ranging from 10 to 250mV s−1. The plots of current versus υ1/2 (Fig. 4b) and υ (Fig. 4c) allow predicting that the mechanism of the electrode process is adsorption or diffusion-controlled (Salimi et al., 2008). In fact, a linear attitude of the current versus scan rate reveals the process obey an adsorption control mechanism, whereas a linear relation of the current versus the square root of the scan rate states the mechanism is diffusion control process. The analysis of data and based on the evaluated R2 values of these plots, a diffusion-controlled process was suggested for the electrode process. A confirmation for this suggestion could be achieved by Randless-Sevcik equation by plotting logIp versus logυ. It is demonstrated that a slope of 0.5 for this plot allows considering a pure diffusion-controlled process (Rezaei and Damiri, 2008). This plot for the acquired data (Fig. 4d) was accompanied with a slope of 0.69, revealing that the electrochemical reaction of DCF on the investigated MIP electrode is controlled by a mixed diffusion/adsorption processes, depends on the scan rate (Salimi et al., 2008). However, it appears that the role of diffusion is more pronounced with respect to that of the adsorption process.

sections.heading: 3.7. Analytical performance of the developed MIP-CP electrode
sections.text:
The electrochemical determination of DCF was realized using the differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) technique using CP, NIP-CP and MIP-CP as working electrodes. DPV has been used because the current
peaks obtained by this technique are sharper and better defined with a lower background current and improved resolution respect to the CV technique (Uslu et al., 2006). The variation of the peak current of DPV as a function of DCF concentration was linear in the range of 5–80mg L−1, by MIP-CP modified electrode (Fig. 5) and demonstrated the greatest sensitivity toward DCF. The significant sensitivity of this electrode was interpreted by considering the presence of the recognition sites in its structure. Eq. (3) describes the linear relation of Ip as a function of DCF concentration, under selected experimental conditions, by applying the prepared MIP-CP electrode:
= +−AI (μ ) 0.5205 C (mg L ) 0.2634p 1 (3)
The corresponding correlation coefficient and limit of detection (LOD) were found to be as 0.9981 and 1.1mg L−1. It is worth of note that the LOD was obtained by using Eqs. (4) and (5);
= +S S 3sm b (4)
= −C (S S)/mm m (5)
where “Sm”, “sb”, “Cm” and m are the signal of the limit of detection, the average current of repeated determinations of blank solution, standard deviation of the blank, limit of detection and slope of the calibration curve, respectively. These values were evaluated by 4 replicate determinations of the blank signals. The calculated of intra-day and interday determination of DCF (20mg L−1) were 2.47% and 2.43% (4 consecutive days) respectively by 4 repeated determinations per day by using the developed sensor.
Reproducibility of the sensor was evaluated by comparing the results of the determination of a solution containing 20mg L−1 of DCF obtained by three independent sensors during three days. The calculated average concentration (22.7 ± 2.0mg L−1 of DCF) demonstrated an appropriate reproducibility of the proposed sensor.

sections.heading: 3.8. Interference effect
sections.text:
Selective attitude of a sensor is a key factor for categorizing it as a successful analytical tool. This characteristic determines whether the concentration of an analyte can be assessed with sufficient accuracy by
the proposed sensor. In pharmaceutical and biological samples there are many concomitant substances which may affect the selectivity of the electrode. In order to check the selectivity of the developed sensor, the samples included DCF and the species which may affect the selectivity of the modified electrodes were analyzed by the proposed method. The examined compounds were glucose (G), ascorbic acid (AA), and urea (U). These compounds were selected because glucose and ascorbic acid exist in blood, and urea is normally found in urine.
The tolerance limit was determined as the concentrations of foreign substances, which gave an error less than±5%. The results of the variation of the peak height observed for DCF in the presence of tested species in the ratios of 1:1–1:1000 (DCF to interferences. in mol L−1). confirm that the presence of ascorbic acid did not affect significantly even at the level of 1000 times greater than the analyte (Table S1). The tolerable ratio of DCF to glucose, at the accepted variation level 5%, was 1:100. It is worth of note that the variation of the peak height
raised to 7.34% by varying the ratio of analyte to glucose to 1:1000. A 10 times of urea with respect to DCF did not alter the determination of the analyte, while by increasing the amount of the interference to 100 times greater than the analyte, an error of about 7.45% was observed.

sections.heading: 3.9. Determination of DCF in real samples
sections.text: In order to demonstrate the applicability of the developed sensor, the DCF contents in two pharmaceutical, and 3 urine samples of the patients under treatment with DCF were analyzed by DPV technique using the modified MIP working electrode. The pharmaceutical samples were commercial diclofenac injection solution (25.0 mgmL−1) and the tablets containing this medicine (50.0 mg per tablet). These samples were prepared by the procedures explained in the experimental section. The results of the triplicate DCF analysis by the developed sensor, together with those obtained by HPLC, as a reference method (Shaalan and Belal, 2013), are presented in Table 1. A comparison of the results presented by the proposed method and those obtained with HPLC were statistically indistinguishable. This was demonstrated by using t-test at the 95% confidence level.

sections.heading: 3.10. Characteristics of the proposed sensor versus some other reported sensors
sections.text: Characteristics and analytical performances of the developed sensor together with those of some previously reported electrochemical sensors for determination of DCF are shown in Table S2. The data revealed that the proposed MIP-CP electrode is suitable analytical performance in terms of low detection limit, wide linear dynamic range, in comparison with reported methods. In addition, the proposed method is simple and does not need to complicated pre-treatment step. A comparison of the selectivity presented by the investigated modified electrode in this work (MIP-CP) with some other sensors reported in the literatures (Goyal et al., 2010), indicated clearly the efficiency of the proposed sensor for the determination of DCF in the presence of the possible interfering species in the other methods.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: A new polyaniline based diclofenac (DCF)-imprinted polymer was prepared and it was used for modification of carbon paste electrode to fabricate a selective DCF electrochemical sensor. The calibration curve for DCF determination was obtained by applying the investigated sensor using as the working electrode in differential pulse voltammetry. Suitable linear range and limit of detection, short time required for DCF analysis, good selectivity and accuracy, low cost and simple preparation process are among the advantages of the proposed sensor. It was shown that the fabricated electrode can be successfully used for determination of DCF in some pharmaceutical and urine samples.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Supplementary material
sections.text: Supplementary data associated with this article can be found in the online version at doi:10.1016/j.bios.2018.09.047.

referenceMentions.context: Diclofenac is a member of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) which are used in remedy of several diseases (Silverstein et al., 2000).
Its carboxymethyl ester derivative is metabolized to DCF and it has also anti-inflammatory activity (Hinz et al., 2003).
cyclooxygenase enzyme which prohibits the production of prostaglandins (Kormosh et al., 2007).

While the medical aspects of DCF are outstanding, it has some side effects such as aplastic anemia, hemolytic anemia, hematological toxicity, hepatitis, neutropenia and thrombocytopenia (Miyamoto et al., 1997).
develop the methods and techniques for its determination in various biological and pharmaceutical samples (Santini et al., 2006).
The techniques already used for determination of DCF included HPLC (Kasperek, 2008), HPLC-MS (Abdel-Hamid et al.
The techniques already used for determination of DCF included HPLC (Kasperek, 2008), HPLC-MS (Abdel-Hamid et al., 2001), TLC (Sun and Fabre, 1994), GC (Sioufi et al.
, 2001), TLC (Sun and Fabre, 1994), GC (Sioufi et al., 1991), derivative spectrophotometry (Ulu, 2011), capillary zone electrophoresis and chemometric methods (Jin and Zhang, 2000).

, 1991), derivative spectrophotometry (Ulu, 2011), capillary zone electrophoresis and chemometric methods (Jin and Zhang, 2000).

Carbon paste electrodes (CPEs) are widely used as working electrode in voltammetric methods because they are applicable in a wide potential range with renewable surface, low cost, simple, and they can be rapidly prepared (Svancara et al., 2001).
In the two past decades, the preparation of MIPs and their applications have attracted the interest of many research groups with different interests (Lingxin et al., 2011).
These cavities are potential to interact selectively with the analyte (template molecule) (Blanco-Lopez et al., 2004).
MIPs have been applied in chemical separations (Wang et al., 2006), preparation of catalysts (Mirata and Resmini, 2015) and development of molecular sensors (Mujahid and Dickert, 2012).
, 2006), preparation of catalysts (Mirata and Resmini, 2015) and development of molecular sensors (Mujahid and Dickert, 2012).

It has been shown that the application of MIPs for modification of working electrodes of voltammetric technique leads to selective methods for determination of various substances (Zakaria et al., 2009; Lian et al., 2015) including DCF (Blanco‐Lopez et al.

In fact, the layered structure allows the diffusion of electrolyte into the interspace of rGO sheets and thus enhances their conductive characteristics (Stankovich et al., 2007).

A comparison of the XRD pattern of the rGO particle prepared electrochemically in this study with that synthesized by chemical methods (Stankovich et al., 2007), demonstrated that the former rGOs bear fewer oxygen containing functional groups.

The observed increase in Ip values was described by considering the role of modifier in increasing the active surface area of the electrode (Kalambate et al., 2016).

DPV has been used because the current peaks obtained by this technique are sharper and better defined with a lower background current and improved resolution respect to the CV technique (Uslu et al., 2006).
The results of the triplicate DCF analysis by the developed sensor, together with those obtained by HPLC, as a reference method (Shaalan and Belal, 2013), are presented in Table 1.

A comparison of the selectivity presented by the investigated modified electrode in this work (MIP-CP) with some other sensors reported in the literatures (Goyal et al., 2010), indicated clearly the efficiency of the proposed sensor for the determination of DCF in the presence of the possible interfering species in the other methods.

metadata.abstractText: A diclofenac (DCF)-imprinted polymer, composed of polyaniline, reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and triphenylamine, as cross linker, was synthetized. This composite was identified by using SEM and FT-IR techniques. The prepared DCF-imprinted polymer (MIP) was used for modification of carbon paste electrodes (CPEs) to fabricate a selective DCF electrochemical sensor. Electrochemical behavior of DCF on the investigated sensor and the optimization of the parameters affecting the DCF determination were screened by cyclic voltammetry (CV). The cyclic voltammogram of DCF showed an anodic peak current at about 0.5 V (vs. SCE). The calibration curve for DCF determination was obtained by applying the investigated sensor as working electrode in differential pulse voltammetry (DPV). A linear increase in the anodic peak current was observed in the range 5–80mg L of DCF. The corresponding limit of detection was calculated to be 1.1 mg L. The relative standard deviations of the interand intra-day analysis of DCF presented by the method were found to be as 2.43% and 2.47%, respectively. The selectivity of the investigated sensor was evaluated by its use for determination of DCF in the binary solutions containing DCF/glucose, DCF/urea and DCF/ascorbic acid. It was shown that the fabricated electrode can be successfully used for analysis of DCF in pharmaceutical and urine samples.
